  1813. I have been eying this product for nearly a year. After two decades of rough feet with nasty heels, I wanted something that would work. I don't like socks on my feet, the PediEgg only works if you use it consistently (and even then it's not 100% great), and I knew that after reading and seeing the pictures of this product that it would be good for me to use. I even had a friend who saw me share a link for it and she bought it for her husband---who it worked on!<br /><br />Anyway, back to MY review. I did lots of research before using this product and when it arrived, I was ready to give it a whirl. I soaked my feet for 15 minutes, dried them off, and then put my feet in the plastic, gel-filled booties. Then I used socks to cover my feet and the booties and sat in my bed, letting the acid stuff do its work for a couple of hours. After the two hours was up, I washed my feet with soap and water and went to bed.<br /><br />For the next three nights after using the Baby Foot, I soaked my feet in my bathtub for at LEAST 15 minutes. After that, I just was kind of over perching on the edge of the tub and decided to forgo soaking. In the meantime, as each day passed and after I soaked my feet and would shower, my feet felt exceptionally dry and borderline itchy---no biggie. By the 5th day, my feet started to flake a little on the bottoms. By the end of week one? HOLY COW! My feet started peeling off in all sorts of layers. What really got me was the skin that peeled at the backs of my heels and at the beginning of the heel of my foot (nearest my instep). A-FREAKING-MAZING! It took off I don't know HOW many layers of skin. Then for the next week plus, my feet continued to peel all over. The bottoms, the heels, the toes, the tops, the sides: EVERYWHERE. Now, almost three weeks after using the product, my feet (except my awful heels that will take multiple uses to get rid of) are super soft and baby smooth. In fact, I had to haul across a ton of parking lots at the Royals game this past Sunday night (8/31) and the balls of my feet burned as the calluses had been removed from them due to the Baby Foot.<br /><br />TIPS<br />-Soak your feet at LEAST 15 minutes before putting on the booties.<br />-If you have extremely bad heels (like me), I think using a PediEgg or whatever you prefer to use to get the layers of skin down somewhat would help the results in the end.<br />-DO NOT walk around if possible in these booties. You will slip and fall. I made it from my bed to the bathroom and nearly fell when I tried to step into the tub.<br />-Soak your feet EVERY DAY for at LEAST 15 minutes for a good week. I think if I had done this, it would have helped my heels more.<br />-I know that it says not to peel your skin, but...it really doesn't hurt. Just be careful that you don't try peeling the skin too deep or it HURTS.<br /><br />I am SUPER excited to purchase this product again in a few weeks so I can use it again. Will PediEgg my heels every night for a few nights before and will see if that helps, as well as soaking my feet longer and more often.this past Sunday night (8/31) and the balls of my feet burned as the calluses had been removed from them due to the Baby Foot.<br /><br />TIPS<br />-Soak your feet at LEAST 15 minutes before putting on the booties.<br />-If you have extremely bad heels (like me), I think using a PediEgg or whatever you prefer to use to get the layers of skin down somewhat would help the results in the end.<br />-DO NOT walk around if possible in these booties. You will slip and fall. I made it from my bed to the bathroom and nearly fell when I tried to step into the tub.<br />-Soak your feet EVERY DAY for at LEAST 15 minutes for a good week. I think if I had done this, it would have helped my heels more.<br />-I know that it says not to peel your skin, but...it really doesn't hurt.   1814. Normally I don't write lengthy reviews but in this case I'm making an exception. Baby Foot is amazing. There is no other way to describe it. Here's my story: I normally get pedicures about once every couple months because overall I thought my feet were healthy and I only had issues with really dry skin on my heels. A lady at the nail salon told me about Baby Foot and I came online to do some research. I was somewhat skeptical about the product but after reading so many positive reviews I decided to try it for myself. I received the product a week ago exactly. From having read other customer reviews I chose to alter the process just a bit for myself. I did a 20 minute foot soak in hot water then applied the booties. They felt slimy and cold when I put them on but after I put on socks over the booties my feet felt better. After about 10-15 minutes my feet starting tingling a little but it was not uncomfortable and eventually passed at around the 30 minute mark. I left the booties on for about 90 minutes total, wanting to get the maximum effects then finished the process by washing them good with soap and water and letting them soak another 15 minutes in plain warm water. Day 3 the tops of my feet looked as if they had a mild case of sunburn and felt a little itchy. I applied plain lotion thinking they might be a little too dry. Day 4 I noticed the bottoms of my feet were starting to peel just a little upon getting out of the shower. Day 5 the top of my feet starting looking even drier and even applying lotion didn't help. Day 6 while drying my feet after a shower a whole section of dead skin sloughed off the top of my feet and I noticed the skin on the bottoms was starting to peel off with vigorous rubbing from the towel. Today is day 7 and I just spent 20 minutes peeling huge sections of dead skin from my feet. It was almost scary to see how much skin I simply peeled away. They look horrible right now because it appears there is still much more peeling to come and I won't be wearing sandals anytime soon until the process is completed. I can tell though that even at this point the skin underneath what has peeled away looks healthy and smooth. I can hardly wait to see the end results but I'm so excited that this product absolutely seems to be doing what it promised and is removing all the dry dead skin that I wasn't even aware had built up on my feet!!!peeling to come and I won't be wearing sandals anytime soon until the process is completed.   1854. Baby Foot sells for $25 from other websites so the $20 price at Amazon was a considerable savings. I applied it on 1/8/13. (And you really should Remain Seated once you get those booties on! They are VERY slippery to walk in on carpet, wood floors, even bathroom tiles.) The directions said leave the booties on for 1 hour but I have 1/2 inch thick layer of dead, calloused skin on both heels, so I kept them on for 1.5 hours. (I showered before using the booties, so my feet were already softened a bit from the water.) Peeling didn't begin until day 6 (the box says peeling will start in 3-5 days). The exfoliation wasn't nearly as good as I had hoped. I got some peeling along the sides of my feet & between my toes. My feet even got flaky across the tops where there wasn't any dead skin...? I soaked them in warm water & scrubbed both feet with a Ped Egg yesterday to accelerate the process. But the dead skin on my heels is still there, along with that weird, corn-like thing on the bottom of my right foot just below my 2nd toe. (Although it has softened a bit, but not enough to slice it off myself.)<br /><br />Clearly, BABY FOOT did not work as promised. If it requires 2 treatments (many reviews have said it does, so I ordered another box when I had no peeling by day 5), they should either cut the price to $10 or sell 2 treatments per box for $20. It's overpriced considering that the first 3 ingredients are water & rubbing alcohol! You'll get better results from a $25 pedicure at your local Asian nail salon than with Baby Foot. But I will post another review after doing a 2nd application tomorrow.<br /><br />- RC<br /><br />BABY FOOT ingredients:<br />Water, Alcohol, Isopropyl Alcohol, Lactic Acid, Glycolic Acid, Arginine, Parfum, Butylene Glycol, Peg-60 Hydrogenetad Castor Oil, Glucose, O-Cymen-5-Ol, Citric Acid, Malic Acid, Citrus Aurantium Dulcis(Orange) Peel Oil, Citrus Grandis(Grapefruit)Peel Oil, Dipotassium Glycyrrhizate, Cymbopogon Schoenanthus Oil, Nasturtium Officinale Extract, Arctium Lappa Root Extract, Saponaria Officinalis Leaf Extract, Hedera Helix(Ivy) Extract, Salvia Officinalis(Sage)Leaf Extract, Citrus Lemon Fruit Extract, Clematis Vitalba Leaf Extract, Spiraea Ulmaria Extract, Equisetum Arvense Extract, Fucus Vesiculosus Extract, Chamomilla Recutita(Matricaria) Flower Extract, Camellia Sinensis Leaf Extract, Houttuynia Cordata Extract, Phenoxyethanol, Hydroxy-ethylcellulose, Salicylic Acid, Sodium Nitrate, Glyoxal, Disodium Phosphate, Linalool, Limonene.inale Extract, Arctium Lappa Root Extract, Saponaria Officinalis Leaf Extract, Hedera Helix(Ivy) Extract, Salvia Officinalis(Sage)Leaf Extract, Citrus Lemon Fruit Extract, Clematis Vitalba Leaf Extract, Spiraea Ulmaria Extract, Equisetum Arvense Extract, Fucus Vesiculosus Extract, Chamomilla Recutita(Matricaria) Flower Extract, Camellia Sinensis Leaf Extract, Houttuynia Cordata Extract, Phenoxyethanol, Hydroxy-ethylcellulose, Salicylic Acid, Sodium Nitrate, Glyoxal, Disodium Phosphate, Linalool, Limonene.

  1861. I had read a lot of good reviews before I purchased Baby Foot and watched the videos to make sure I would follow the instructions correctly and what was successful for other purchasers. So I was really excited to order it. The product did not come in the package that was shown on this website. It came in an envelope that was labeled with an online beauty company . I opened the package and the only thing in the package was a silver bag with no instructions just a packaging slip. There was no box enclosed. No directions either. I opened the silver envelope and discovered the booties with the solution in it. I said I had watched the videos and the booties did not look like anything like the ones that were shown. It had a blue strip across the top with no tape to hold it closed. I was still determined so I used clear packaging tape to hold the booties on. (don't laugh) I soaked my feet for 45 minutes, dried them off and sat in a chair with the gooey booties on for 2 hours. I rinsed my feet and soaked them 5-10 minutes and dried them off really good. Here it is day 6 and nothing at all has happened. I take a bath every day and was looking for some kind of progress. To my disappointment my feet are rough, calloused and look basically like they did before I used the product. I honestly do not think I got what ordered. Has this happened to anyone else?
  1862. That may be hyperbole, but what this does is nothing short of miraculous. I have clinically dry skin and I live in New England, so it's prone to harsh winters. This product peels dry, dead skin off effortlessly.<br /><br />After applying, my skin starts to peel within 3-4 days. Keep in mind that once the peeling process starts, it's a little out of control. I wear thick socks to help it peel and keep the skin contained. (I know some people would find it gross, but I actually find it so satisfying when it comes off in large pieces!)<br /><br />I will keep buying this as long as they make it...between this and coconut oil, it makes sloughing feet the old fashioned way obsolete.<br /><br />Note: It says not to use while pregnant or nursing, but I got my doctor's OK to use during breastfeeding (I didn't want to use it while pregnant, though). I'm not sure why it has this warning, so if anyone knows, I'd love to hear it...if you're thinking about using anyway, definitely check with your dr.

  1876. Will have to order again soon.
  1877. This is a great product! For me, the process was pretty much finished eight days after application, but the quickness might have been due to what I did during those eight days.<br /><br />Application day: I soaked my feet for 30 minutes, towel dried them, applied the gel-filled booties, put on a pair of socks over that and sat with my feet flat on the floor for one hour. I then removed the socks and booties, washed with soap and water and towel dried. I did not soak my feet afterwards because it seemed that would be counterintuitive--I had just spent an hour letting the stuff soak into my feet, so I didn't want to dilute the effects by immediately soaking in water afterwards. My feet felt kind of tingly, but nothing bad.<br /><br />Day 1: The following day my feet felt tight, kind of like how your skin feels with a slight sunburn, but no stinging or anything. Nothing appeared noticeably different. I soaked my feet for 30 minutes in a basin of water that evening.<br />Day 2: Again, same tight feeling, as well as dry. Soaked feet for 30 minutes that evening, then applied a little bit of lotion.<br />Day 3: Not feeling quite as tight/dry, no noticeable appearance difference. We went on mini vacation to the beach--spent about two hours in the water.<br />Day 4: Feels like I've got stockings/hose on my feet. Noticed a tiny bit of peeling on my toes. Spent about five hours in the ocean.<br />Day 5: Back home. Feet are peeling on and around toes, on the bottom, pieces about half the size of a postage stamp. Soak feet for 30 minutes in basin of water.<br />Day 6: Dead skin is peeling off in sheets, especially across the arch/soles of feet. Calluses are starting to peel off. Soak feet for 30 minutes, use a rough washcloth to lightly scrub, then soap and rinse. Note: As sheets of skin peel off, the tight hose feeling disappears.<br />Day 7: Lots of baby pink, soft skin showing. Most of the bottom of the feet has peeled. Minor peeling on top of feet, along sides. Soak feet for 30 minutes, use rough washcloth to really scrub.<br />Day 8: Toes, bottom of feet and up sides to ankles have completely peeled. There is a slight amount of dead skin still coming off the top of the feet, but after soaking for 30 minutes, scrubbing with a washcloth, towel drying and applying some lotion, it is not noticeable at all.<br /><br />Things I noted: My feet are much softer. Places where I had thick calluses are not completely callus-free, but they are substantially reduced. A second application after two weeks would probably take care of the rest. The calluses were the last part to start peeling. Toes were first, in-between toes second, soles of feet (minus the areas of callus) third, sides and top next, and calluses last. I think (though not sure) it might be due to the fact that it's harder for the product to penetrate the thick skin of the calluses, hence the thinner areas peel first and the thicker areas last. I also think my excursion into the ocean hastened the peeling process, since my feet were submerged in water for hours over a two-day period.<br /><br />In my opinion this product is worth the money, and I will use it again in the future.along sides. Soak feet for 30 minutes, use rough washcloth to really scrub.<br />Day 8: Toes, bottom of feet and up sides to ankles have completely peeled. There is a slight amount of dead skin still coming off the top of the feet, but after soaking for 30 minutes, scrubbing with a washcloth, towel drying and applying some lotion, it is not noticeable at all.<br /><br />Things I noted: My feet are much softer. Places where I had thick calluses are not completely callus-free, but they are substantially reduced. A second application after two weeks would probably take care of the rest. The calluses were the last part to start peeling. Toes were first, in-between toes second, soles of feet (minus the areas of callus) third, sides and top next, and calluses last. I think (though not sure) it might be due to the fact that it's harder for the product to penetrate the thick skin of the calluses, hence the thinner areas peel first and the thicker areas last. I also think my excursion into the ocean hastened the peeling process, since my feet were submerged in water for hours over a two-day period.<br /><br />In my opinion this product is worth the money, and I will use it again in the future.

  1887. The packaging and use of the product were both positive. I liked how it was a no-muss, no-fuss application. My criticism comes from what happened after. My feet felt soft immediately after removal, but still had hard skin. Over a week later, with no other sign of the product having worked at all, all of a sudden, my feet started peeling -- the night before I had plans to go to a pool party. There were huge sections of skin flaking off the bottoms, tops and sides of my feet. If it were just that reaction, it still would have been OK, because the sections that had peeled really were &#34;baby foot soft.&#34; Unfortunately, the peeling continues for a couple of days and once it's complete, some areas (like the heel) had already started hardening again, while others were beautiful. It's not a consistent peel and I wouldn't recommend using the product during the couple of week period where your feet will be exposed publicly, through shoes, pool decks, etc., as you might get a few looks, however, if you're looking for soft feet in the dead of winter, when no one but you and your housemates might see, then it's worth it. Either way, the effects are not long lasting.

  1956. All I have to say is it just works. It's an awful (not painful) experience for about a week as you constantly shed dead skin. You'll find dead skin throughout your house for weeks afterwards, so wear socks as much as you can. It'll be at the bottom of your bed, under the sheets, rugs, carpet, bathroom tile...but even though it's a mess, it's so satisfying to know you're getting rid of the nasty dead skin on your feet.<br /><br />Just one more note, it does not remove a callus. I would recommend using a Ped Egg or other product to remove as much of the callus as you can before using Baby Foot. Also, per the instructions, soak your feet in warm water right before using, I used Epsom salt. After your feet are completely exfoliated, to prolong the baby soft skin, buy foot cream and wear socks.<br /><br />Just a great product all around!
  1957. It took longer that I had expected for the peeling to begin, about 10 days, but good gracious, once it started I looked like a lizard monster! You can't wear any type of shoes that show your feet during the peeling process--which is still ongoing for me. I can't wear my business pumps to work, so you should plan to work for home for at least a week or more, depending on how much longer this peeling continues. Your feet definitely look unpresentable (and absolutely ridiculous) while peeling. The only thing I've found that covers it up is socks up to my ankles and tennis shoes. I mean, it's a freaky mess, so I hope it's worth it when it's all over. It's definitely a product for people who can stay at home a lot. But, I can't really knock the product, it did what it said, and I commend it for that. It definitely made my feet peel...and peel and peel. The package just might want to warn people that they will be homebound and their feet will be unpresentable to the public for a long while during the peeling process.

  1960. My feet have a tendency to get calloused, and it's pretty difficult to get rid of the dead skin that develops on the heels. Scrubs are great for light exfoliation, but anyone with dry, cracked heels will tell you that even the most luxurious scrubs do nothing in that department. I was skeptical when I ordered Baby Foot, but the slew of good reviews on Amazon - as well as a few on Buzzfeed - prompted me to give it a whirl. At only $20 bucks, I figured it wasn't that much of a risk. Boy am I glad I tried it! Read on...<br /><br />About a week ago, I used the product. I followed the instructions and cleaned/soaked my feet beforehand, and then slipped on the booties (the smell is pretty wonderful). I put socks over those and watched TV for the next hour (warning: don't walk around while wearing the booties, as you might slip and injure yourself). After sitting still for exactly one hour, I rinsed the gel-like residue from my feet and went on with my life.<br /><br />Over the next few days, nothing miraculous occurred. My feet were still dry, chapped, and gross. Exactly six days after my &#34;treatment&#34;, I decided to soak my feet in some warm water (peeling occurs within 5-7 days, and I hoped this would help facilitate the peeling process). I filled a foot bath with hot water and Epsom salts and relaxed for an hour. I was not prepared for what I saw when I took my feet out of the water...<br /><br />SKIN. Chunks of rubbery, white, dead skin were hanging off my feet. It didn't hurt at all, and as I excitedly pulled away the dead layers (much like a child ripping the paper off a Christmas package), I saw healthy, new skin beneath. It was a miracle! I almost had a heart attack, but in a happy way.<br /><br />Sometimes, beauty treatments can be gross before they work. My feet are still peeling a bit, but I am hooked. This method is so much easier than furiously scrubbing at your dead skin with a Ped Egg, or some other exfoliator. Just make sure you follow the instructions, and 5-7 days after the treatment, soak your feet thoroughly. You won't be disappointed.ak your feet thoroughly. You won't be disappointed.
  1961. It worked fairly well, but my feet weren't THAT smooth after I removed the dead skin, but much more smoother than if I had gone to a nail shop. Be aware that your feet are going to continue to 'shed' for at least two to three weeks after you use it. I don't regret the purchase.

It's been several weeks since I used it and my feet are still 1000X better than before I did it.   1990. I purchased this product, because I have a few stubborn hard spots that never get completely removed in spite of regular pumicing. Yes, soaking my feet in a mild acid until they start to molt sounded extreme, but I wanted extreme. I was ready to take the next step in foot care, and get rid of those hard spots. I followed the instructions exactly, including pre-soaking my feet. I then waited several days, while my feet looked exactly the same, and fought the urge to pumice away the dead spots. Just as promised, the feet started to shed like crazy approximately five days after I first used the product. But a closer observation revealed that they were mostly shedding healthy skin, such as the skin along the arches of my feet. The hardened parts on the balls and toes lost only a thin layer of surface skin--the same thin layer that I lost from the arches of my feet, which do not regularly have any dead skin. The result is that it looks like my feet received a good lotion and pumicing. They don't have visible dead skin, but they still have several hard spots to the touch--nothing like a &#34;baby's foot.&#34; That would be alright, if I hadn't undergone two weeks of extremely, ugly feet (waiting for the peeling to start, and having feet that looked like a lizard in full molt) to get this result.<br /><br />Bottom Line: If you know how to effectively pumice your feet, stick to it. This product is a lot of hassle for results that aren't better.
  1991. I have used this product three times over the past two years. It kind of works, in that it does peel a layer of skin off your feet. I have found; however that it does not get rid of the deep cracks and fissures of the heels.<br /><br />Don't get me wrong; the process is so cool. Over the period of about ten days the skin on your feet will peel off in sheets...and that is awesome! It's like a science experiment on your body. It does not hurt at all unless you try to peel the skin yourself. I am a picker and the first time I did this I pulled on the peeling skin, but I ended up with sore spots; almost like when you peel a sunburn. Don't do it. Just fight the urge tug.<br /><br />The best peels come after you have bathed or showered. The skin just sloughs off your feet. You will leave dead skin on the carpet, couch, chairs...everywhere. It's kind of gross, but kind of neat too in an &#34;eeew&#34; sort of way.<br /><br />This product is good for freshening up the look of your feet, but again; it won't heal them. Oh I just remembered! One thing that was really neat was that it faded some scars I had on my feet from old blisters. It really lessened the appearance of those old scars. It smells great too.<br /><br />Every woman owes it to herself to try this at least once.
